newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria seeks funds to reduce coal pollution.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria seeks funds to reduce coal pollution.

text.p: Bulgaria is seeking funds to develop a sulphur reduction project to curb pollution from its biggest coal mining and thermal power complex, Maritsa East, an energy official said on Thursday.

Bulgarian Atomic Energy Committee chairman Lachezar Kostov said Japanese experts were helping Bulgaria work out a pilot project using electronic technology to reduce pollution from the high-sulphur lignite coal.
Kostov said the International Atomic Energy Agency will extend aid of some $1.5 million for the project and Bulgaria must provide some $1 million.
"Japan is giving us the installation, worth $4 million, free," Kostov told a news conference. "We are seeking another $700,000."
Environmental officials say lignite from Maritsa East has one of the highest sulphur contents in Europe and Bulgaria's outdated thermal power stations are among the worst polluters in the country.
Maritsa East, 250 km south-east of Sofia, has only lignite coal and its reserves of some two billion tonnes are expected to feed the country's coal-fired power stations for another 80 to 100 years.
Bulgaria relies on Maritsa East for 30 percent of its electricity needs and the nuclear power plant at Kozloduy meets more than 40 percent of the country's power demand.
